title: AI-Generated Proof Strategy
description: A structured representation of a single proof strategy proposed by an AI assistant, designed for evaluation and synthesis.

strategist.description: The name or version of the AI model that generated this strategy (e.g., 'Gemini 2.5 Pro', 'GPT-5 via Codex').

method.description: A concise, high-level name for the proposed proof technique (e.g., 'Mild Formulation + Fixed-Point Argument', 'Contradiction via Subgradient Calculus').

summary.description: A brief narrative summary explaining the core insight and logical flow of the proposed strategy.

keySteps.description: An ordered list of the main logical stages required to execute the proof.

strengths.description: A list of the primary advantages of this proof strategy.

weaknesses.description: A list of potential disadvantages, risks, or technical difficulties associated with this strategy.

frameworkDependencies.description: A structured list of all axioms, theorems, lemmas, and definitions from the framework required to execute this strategy.

technicalDeepDives.description: An analysis of the most technically challenging parts of the proposed strategy, including a sketch of their resolution.

confidenceScore.description: The AI's self-assessed confidence in the viability and completeness of its proposed strategy.

dependencyList.description: A list of specific framework dependencies of a certain type (e.g., Theorems).

label.description: The unique identifier for the dependency.

document.description: The source document where the dependency is defined.

purpose.description: A brief summary of what this dependency provides for the proof.

usedInSteps.description: A list of identifiers for the 'keySteps' that rely on this dependency.

technicalChallenge.description: An analysis of a specific technical challenge within the proof strategy.

challengeTitle.description: A short name for the challenge.

difficultyDescription.description: An explanation of why this part of the proof is difficult.

proposedSolution.description: A sketch of the technique or argument to overcome the challenge.

references.description: Citations to external literature or other framework results that support the proposed solution.
